captions.text:
ALEX ROY: I've loved cars
ever since I was a kid.

And I dream that someday I might
even drive some of these

cars, maybe even make a
car show of my own.

Today, I'm on Drive,
and I feel like the
luckiest guy in the world.

And among my favorite shows
happens to be another show on
Drive, Chris Harris on Cars.

So I sent him an email
saying that.

I mean the guy's
got an E24 M5.
And he sent me one back.

He didn't quite say, my
show was his favorite.

But he did invite me to a secret
location in Wales,

which is where I went to
meet him in person.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

ALEX ROY: Everything I know
about the United Kingdom, I

learned from an amazing
documentary called Braveheart.

But on the way to the hilltop
Chris had given me to put into

the GPS, I entered into the most
beautiful countryside,

undulating hills, Vermont
with fog and sheep.

I love veal but not as much as
the two cars Chris had waiting

for us to drive on the hilltop
at my destination.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

CHRIS HARRIS: When JF said you
were going to drop by and say

hello, and I thought,
they've got to come.

We've got to take
them to the pub.
We've done that.

But you didn't get
to see that.

And I'm going to cook them
some mutton, some
good Welsh old lamb.

What I wanted to do is to
present to you the cars that I

thought would be of interest to
you, because you don't have
them where you live.

So I thought I'd line up a lot
of couple of French hatchbacks

because that's not what you get
in North America, small,

light, small amount of power,
and you have to work hard to
get the performance from them.

And then Alex casually tells me
that his father used to be

the importer for Citroen
in the States.

And he's driven every old French
car under the sun and
used to have a 305 GTI 1.6.
ALEX ROY: And an AX Diesel.

CHRIS HARRIS: Thank
you for [BLEEP]
on my past.
ALEX ROY: Sorry.

CHRIS HARRIS: So what
I've done is I've
brought this along.

You might have seen it in
an earlier Drive video.

But I've spent a bit of
time in this car.

It's a Clio 200 with
a cup chassis.
On it.

And I'll coin my own phrase
earlier I think if I had to

take an essence of a car with
me to my grave, I'd probably

have this thing crushed up
into a ball and stuffed--
ALEX ROY: Over any other car?
How come?

CHRIS HARRIS: Because I am known
to love these things.
I love these things.

I could talk about them
forever, so I won't.

There is a ubiquity
about these cars.

They are pretty much an
everyman proposition.

I know that they do
cost some money.

But if you want to go and drive
this car, you'll always
have a great time.

And to turn that around, I think
that if you can't find

fun in this car, you're probably
not a car enthusiast.

ALEX ROY: He probably thought it
was really funny to bring a

GT3 3.8 and a Renault Clio
Sport or S. He probably

thought I'd find the irony
between the two different cars
being so different funny.

But actually I really
love small
Renaults, small hot hatches.

And I used to own
a Renault Clio.

And I actually wanted to drive
that car more than I wanted to
drive the Porsche.
CHRIS HARRIS: Look at it.
[INAUDIBLE].

ALEX ROY: I had the benefit of
having an amazing excuse for

not being that quick
in the Renault.

All right, will you do me a
favor, and just make sure that

you keep reminding me to stick
to the left, unless I'm too

far left, in which case,
I'm going to come back?

Which is that, I had to drive on
the wrong side of the road,

or as he pointed out, I always
drive on the wrong side, and

today I have to drive
on the correct side.

CHRIS HARRIS: First of all, we
need to get your driving
position sorted out.

ALEX ROY: You don't like
my driving position?

CHRIS HARRIS: No, I want you
to sit more upright in this

car, a little bit
more upright.
Think of it as English class.

If you slouch in class, you're
not going to concentrate.
ALEX ROY: Right.
CHRIS HARRIS: Now we're away.
ALEX ROY: All right.
Can I go to the left?

CHRIS HARRIS: No, go to the
right, a bit up there.
Here we go.

Do you ever refer to this manual
gear box as just a
stick shift?
ALEX ROY: A stick.

You know also, I should say
about my seating position, and

I hate to bring this up again,
I drive using the Citroen SM

seating position, which is
almost prone, the steering
wheel almost horizontal.
I like this car.

You've got to keep it
above 4,000 for
anything fun to happen.

CHRIS HARRIS: You do have to
rev it, rev it, rev it.
ALEX ROY: But it's really fun.

And it's super twitchy,
everything is super
responsive.

I don't drive a lot of small
cars, but it reminds me of my
911 with half the power.

CHRIS HARRIS: [INAUDIBLE]
beautiful.

There appears to be a box
of bolts in the boot.

ALEX ROY: I asked
them about that.

But Renault said that
it came stock.
[LAUGHING]

CHRIS HARRIS: There is also a
trick from my childhood in

here, which is that when you've
got a hatchback, and

you can't afford [INAUDIBLE],
just always have the rear

seats folded because
it sounds noisier.
ALEX ROY: The car is cool.

Like you said, there is a lot
of torque, bring it out.
And it's fun.
What does this car cost?

CHRIS HARRIS: This is about
15,000 or 16,000 pounds or so.
ALEX ROY: So $25,000.
It's a bargain.

CHRIS HARRIS: It's a bargain for
that, but, of course, you

guys get so much more
value over there.

ALEX ROY: If you
could buy this.

But over there, back home, what
do you buy that's even in
the universe of this?
A GTI?

CHRIS HARRIS: Is there
anything that's close
to this in the US?
ALEX ROY: A GTI.
CHRIS HARRIS: That's it?
And what are they?
ALEX ROY: 25, 30.
So it's in the universe.

I mean how much is an FR--
what's it called FRS?
CHRIS HARRIS: Oh, the GT86.
[INAUDIBLE]
ALEX ROY: Yeah.
What does that car cost?

CHRIS HARRIS: I think that's
a bit more, isn't it?
ALEX ROY: I don't know.

The truth is I'm not paying
attention because I've owned a

Subaru WRX which costs,
at the time, 25ish.

And to be honest with you, I'd
rather own that than this.

And I mean we don't have to go
into the reasons, but that's a

lot more value than this
would be at 25.
CHRIS HARRIS: Oh, absolutely.

But there is one thing that I
find interesting about this

car, if you want to take your
brain out and just absolutely

grab a car by the scruff
of the neck--
ALEX ROY: Can I pass?
Is that legal?

CHRIS HARRIS: Don't
do it here.

Because we are going to
turn around just here
and then come back.

And there is nothing better than
overtaking someone and

then stopping immediately
[INAUDIBLE].

ALEX ROY: None of that made a
difference because I nearly

went off into the bushes
and struck
several sheep many times.
Oh, my God.

CHRIS HARRIS: What do you
think he's doing?
Eating a bit of his own brain?

ALEX ROY: Scouting
for Bordeaux.
CHRIS HARRIS: He's not clever.

He's looking for the bright
part of the gene pool.

ALEX ROY: I love veal but not
when prepared by a Renault.

CHRIS HARRIS: So what do you
think of the whole driving on

Welsh roads [INAUDIBLE]
sheep around you?

ALEX ROY: So far this is
the best drive I've
ever seen in England.
Oh, sorry.
Put this in the ditch.

CHRIS HARRIS: No, that
was the right line.
ALEX ROY: OK.
You say.

Earlier in the day, he intimated
that I would get to
drive the Porsche.

It did not come as a surprise
after my experience driving

him in the Renault that that
opportunity somehow
evaporated.

So there is no real discussion
or review of this car because
you love it.

CHRIS HARRIS: Yeah, it's a
bit predictable isn't it?

We should be in something
else.

ALEX ROY: So I was about to
warn you about traffic

on-coming, but , of course,
that's the wrong lane.

CHRIS HARRIS: You're just
tired aren't you?

ALEX ROY: No, just what people
say about Americans driving on
the wrong side.

CHRIS HARRIS: Did you do
the Gumball in Europe?

ALEX ROY: Yeah, I did drive a
Bentley GT around the world

with a friend of mine that has
one, a right-hand drive car.

CHRIS HARRIS: So your only
experience of driving a

right-hand drive care is driving
around the world?

ALEX ROY: But it was
an automatic.

CHRIS HARRIS: It's like I've
only read one book,
it was War and Peace.
ALEX ROY: OK.

It wasn't all the way
around the world.
It was part of the way.

And also the car is
a battleship.
So it's much easier.
I mean it is what it is.

CHRIS HARRIS: It's a predictable
car, but it's a
really good car.

And this one is worthy
of special review
because it's blue.
ALEX ROY: It sounds so good.

CHRIS HARRIS: So when they bring
out different colored

ones, we'll have to review
them as well.
ALEX ROY: Oh, god.

CHRIS HARRIS: But apparently
next month
they've got a green one.

So I'll need that for a couple
of weeks as well.

I'm going to be rigorous with
this stuff, I need to know

what this blue paint
is like on speed.

ALEX ROY: I cowered in mortal
fear as we went up
and down that road.

CHRIS HARRIS: What other car
would you want [INAUDIBLE]?

ALEX ROY: Oh, god, it sounds
so-- oh, god, sheep.

CHRIS HARRIS: Yeah, there are
some sheeps out tonight.

It's lambing season, so you've
got a combination of stupid

old sheep and stupid
young sheep.

ALEX ROY: And let's
be serious.

How frequently do you review
cars on this road?
CHRIS HARRIS: Quite a lot.

ALEX ROY: So even just like the
last crest, I would never

do because I'm terrified
of sheep.

CHRIS HARRIS: There are
different hill sheep in
different areas of Wales.

Like Mountain Road, the sheep
are a bit more stupid.

Around here, I think the
sheep are a bit clever.
I think I'll slow down here.

ALEX ROY: Are you being snarky,
or do sheep really not
go into the road here?
CHRIS HARRIS: No.
They do now and again.

But you just can't live
your life like that.
ALEX ROY: Right.

I can't believe I'm saying
this, but I may be in the

point in my life where
I really enjoy a slow
car and a soft ride.

CHRIS HARRIS: It's quite firm
on this road, isn't it?

ALEX ROY: The reason I like
Chris's videos is because as a

writer, he is attempting to
convey in videos things that

one would only expect
to learn in writing.

CHRIS HARRIS: I've always felt
that the one way to perhaps

present being a car enthusiast
in the moving form, in what I

call the topical era, is that
just, A, not try to be them

because they are brilliant
at what they do.

And I'm not just doing this
because I'm terrified of them
ruining my life.

But they are brilliant
at what they do.

Never try and impersonate people
who are brilliant,

because you'll only
look like an ass.
You really will.

And I will look like an ass if
I try to impersonate them.

But there is a certain number
of people that want to see

something that is a bit more
defined for the car
enthusiast.

They want to see maybe a bit
more expert feedback on the
latest cars.

They want to see a bit
more expert driving.

And, me, I'm not saying I'm the
man to do that, but maybe,

if that is where my strengths
lie, you've got to do that.

I also think that rather than go
out and create content, you
need to reverse the process.

You need to create yourself an
interesting life with cars.

However you do it, it
should be natural.
Otherwise, it will look false.

But create an interesting
life with cars.
ALEX ROY: And share that.

CHRIS HARRIS: And just share
that with people.
And if you do that--

all I'm doing really is I'm
doing what I used to do as an
columnist in a car magazine.

ALEX ROY: I grew up reading
Car and Driver, Road and

Track, all of these amazing
car magazines before the
internet existed.

Today, we see these amazing car
reviews, and Chris Harris

is one of the people making
some of the best.

But Chris and I shared something
which ran very deep.

My whole life, I wanted to be
a writer, I wanted to write
about cars.

And Chris, who makes these
amazing videos, said exactly
the same thing.

He wishes he could spend more
time writing about cars.

And that's where he made a name
for himself, writing for
Autocar and Evo.

CHRIS HARRIS: But because of
JF and Josh and, the other

kind of guys-- and Neal that I
work with-- you've got the
chance to share it on form.
That's all.
That's all I'm doing.
It's not rocket science.

I think there is a dozen, two
dozen, three dozen, four dozen

other people that can do it
just as well as I can.
I'm lucky.

I've got a really good platform,
and somebody's given
me the chance to do it.

ALEX ROY: Within five minutes
of meeting Chris, we're

sitting on the hoods of these
cars, shooting the [BLEEP]
as if we were old friends.

You get two old friends
together, and they can go on
all night about anything.

But of all the cars I've ever
owned, the one that I derive

the greatest driving pleasure
from, and I have taken to the
track a little bit--

but even cruising at 20 miles an
hour just my life is better
for it-- is this '87 Targa.

It's got 120,000 miles, 3.2
liter G50 transmission.

And for me, it's the
purest sports car I
feel I've ever owned.
But wait.
There's more.

CHRIS HARRIS: I felt like I was
driving a cheap Ferrari.

That has to be the essence
of an Alfa Romeo.
ALEX ROY: That's right.

CHRIS HARRIS: You have to feel
that you've bought into

something Italian that's
offering you something so much

more on an emotional scale that
the Germans or French
can't offer you.

Let's face it, the Germans
are always going to
make a better car.
ALEX ROY: Um, oh, my god.
Yeah.
I totally agree with that.
Yeah.
CHRIS HARRIS: Red [INAUDIBLE].
You don't see it?

I'm saying to Josh,
look at that.
Look at that.

ALEX ROY: And I was saying
to you, oh, my god.
But wait, there is more.

CHRIS HARRIS: Is it acceptable
to just buy a car purely on
aesthetic grounds?

ALEX ROY: I did own an Audi TT
Gen1 convertible with yellow
stitching and red leather.
But wait.
There's more.

CHRIS HARRIS: If we were to go
and transport ourselves Matrix

style now to your SX, and
the battery had power in
it, would it work?
ALEX ROY: Yeah.

CHRIS HARRIS: How far could you
drive it before it would
need attention?

ALEX ROY: All right,
let's be clear.

I drove that car from Los
Angeles to Ensenada, Mexico,

when I did the Baja
1,000 last year.

The alternator belt got twisted
and broke but was

replaced for the equivalent of
$3 in a barn by a Mexican who
spoke no English.

So that car could still be fixed
by a random on the side
of the road.
Can this?

CHRIS HARRIS: You've digressed
so massively from the
question, I'll ask it again.

How far-- if we went
there now--
ALEX ROY: 300 miles.
[LAUGHS]

And to be clear, my good
friend, Gale, who is a

Frenchman who previously worked
for VW now works for

Cadillac, designs interiors for
GM, called me-- he owns

this Trend DS-- he called me
a few days ago and said,

(SPEAKING IN FRENCH ACCENT) my
friend, let us go make a road

trip to Death Valley
to see the eclipse.
I have a new telescope.
It will be amazing.
I'm like awesome.
Let's take the SM.
He's like, are you crazy?
[LAUGHS]

title: When Chris Harris Meets Alex Roy: U.K. Part 1 of 4 - /LIVE AND LET DRIVE

comments.text: Chris harris himself is the new top gear. ﻿
comments.author: nate vandyke

comments.text: Alex is just not funny...﻿
comments.author: Billis DeWillis

comments.text:
Seriously guys, after 1 minute of watching I can tell you Alex is sending 
himself up. If you think any of his mistakes are genuine ones after he 
mentions Braveheart as a documentary then you are the ones who are stupid.﻿
comments.author: Ralph Hardwick

comments.text: I've got a mk6 GTI! Absolutely love it. Hot Hatches ftw!﻿

comments.text:
'I was just beginning to like the guy and then he said that he bought a TT 
cause of its looks' 😆 ﻿

comments.text: Interesting section at 09:07﻿
comments.author: oliverTbest

comments.text:
The shear stupidity of Alex Roy is staggering veal is a baby cow, you 
misquoted it 2 times. (Face Palm)﻿

comments.text:
TURN DOWN THE BLOODY MUSIC, SO WE GET A CHANCE TO REALLY LISTEN To THE 
GREAT COMMENTS FROM THESE GUYS. ﻿

comments.text:
I never even realised i stopped seeing videos by this guy and i have to 
say, i dont miss them he's annoying and christ he's stupid too, really 
sheep everywhere and he can't stop talking about veal!﻿

comments.text: dont sit on the bloody car!﻿

comments.text: Minecraft is awesome k bye

comments.text: E24 M5...lol really shows how much this idiot knows. ﻿
comments.author: Jacob Lee

comments.text: veal is young calf in the UK and USA. c'mon﻿
comments.author: Aaron Cole

comments.text: are you by the horseshoe pass near llangollen ﻿
comments.author: Johnathon Montgomery

comments.text: Music was obnoxious, otherwise great video love Chris﻿
comments.author: Topen Lamp

comments.text: I would love to sit around and chat with these two﻿
comments.author: mzondi1970

comments.text: Haha love the sheep convo ﻿
comments.author: Adam Hansen

comments.text:
The E24 range has an M6, but Chris has (had?) an E28 M5. Tut tut. Basic 
stuff.

The soundtrack caused me to have to stop watching this video after 5 
minutes. You''ve travelled to the UK to drive some performance cars and 
chat with Chris Harris. Which part of this requires an uninterrupted 
techno/jazz soundtrack?﻿
comments.author: colin5577

comments.text: Sheep? Veal? Got to love our American cousins! Bless them!!﻿

comments.text:
I love Chris. such a talented guy. AND, he built arguably the most 
desirable car Iv ever laid eyes on. The 1971 green 911 ST he spent 2 years 
on. Just a brilliant Porsche. Chris rulz!﻿

comments.text: Veal?????? All I can see are sheep, and thus mutton or lamb. ﻿

comments.text: *e28 M5, thats what happened to alex﻿

comments.text: What ever happened to alex...?﻿

comments.text: Stop. Calling. Sheep. Veal! ﻿
comments.author: IdFightMyDad

comments.text:
I know.  once was maybe forgivable, but the fact that he said it twice, and 
in the *overdubbed commentary*, no less (meaning he had the opportunity to 
correct himself after the fact)....  jesus, man.  You don't deserve Veal if 
you don't know what the fuck it is.
comments.author: ceounicom

comments.text: +IdFightMyDad I don't think he is either. If it's a joke it's not very good.
comments.author: staggabob

comments.text: It's. And I don't think he was joking.
comments.author: IdFightMyDad

comments.text: Its. A. Joke!
comments.author: The Coletrain

comments.text:
Love these guys
﻿

comments.text:
I hadn't realised how likable Alex is as a presenter until now, I guess I'm 
a douche for judging so quickly. I am a douche tho :-) It's interesting to 
see how Chris dominates other personalities but he's polite and friendly, 
mostly, so it's ok :-)﻿
comments.author: soogle gucks

comments.text: Alex, where'd you go! Come back, drive is not the same without you.﻿

comments.text: Chk ..john harris 1/5 Lectures ; google
comments.author: kaplash

comments.text: "E24 M5" Don't you mean E28? :P
comments.author: Daniel Mirzotti

comments.text: Anti-Americans, it's a British disease.
comments.author: Centenon

comments.text: This guy's a baffoon!
comments.author: Duncan Keith

comments.text: Can you Drive 2800 miles in 31 hours and 4 min?
comments.author: dugg117

comments.text: and yesterday i went with my kia rio to Mariana trench and back!
comments.author: TheMeridian808

comments.text: by the way, i drove my car from jupiter to mars a couple of times!!!
comments.author: TheMeridian808

comments.text: Racist cunt
comments.author: dilawer321

comments.text:
It's funny - after Chris listened to the idiot blather on, Chris decided 
not to let him drive the Porsche. Right on Chris!!! The jerk is really 
stuck on himself, and it's no wonder this is the first time I've heard of 
him.
comments.author: dooma flatchie

comments.text:
Alex Roy has done some cool shit in the past. He may not be a great 
TV/youtube personality, but he's a gumball rally driver and has broke 
records. Japan's wangan is fucking bad ass, and what Alex is into is very 
similar which I very much enjoy.
comments.author: HypermaxZ

comments.text: No. He's just trying to be funny.
comments.author: msiley

comments.text: ive seen that 911 gb plate so many times.. on road..and tv. top gear etc
comments.author: Blackerflash

comments.text: I now have the rear seats folded in my 200 :). Cheers Chris!!
comments.author: RS133TWING

comments.text: alex roy is so dry and so damn funny
comments.author: theglitchmodulator

comments.text: I miss live and let drive and Roy :(
comments.author: Tim Wepunkt

comments.text:
/DRIVE is my favorite car culture show. Hands down. Even over a TG. And 
it's because of stuff like this and Chris Harris. Thank you.
comments.author: 3rdObstacle

comments.text: i can't understand so few people think he's a douche
comments.author: Dries Nys

comments.text:
There is such a thing as a video being overproduced. Frequent cuts to the 
"artsy" b&w confessional are quite jarring.
comments.author: NonDeUn

comments.text: Sadly, I'm not convinced..!
comments.author: HeavensGremlin

comments.text: That was a joke. Fucking hell.
comments.author: The Coletrain

comments.text: lol joke's on you i guess.
comments.author: Josh Vietze

comments.text: Alex Roy is an idiot. and ruined my day.
comments.author: jack black

comments.text: Alex Roy is fucking great u guys need to cut him slack
comments.author: Guywithacar

comments.text:
He asks him if he likes Welsh roads and he then says he is in England. What 
a plonker.
comments.author: mmtot

comments.text:
Lol since when has "veal" the meat from a calf (a baby cow for those too 
dumb to know what a calf is) got anything to do with sheep? The meat of a 
young sheep is called "lamb" and older sheep is called "mutton"
comments.author: Loki Jotunn

comments.text: this guy is arrogant and a douche. chris is a legend though
comments.author: Daniel Marshall

comments.text:
"Everything I know about the UK I learnt from a DOCUMENTARY called 
'Braveheart' " DOCUMENTARY...??????? Holy fuck, just when I think I'm too 
hard on Americans, I hear stuff like this and I'm back to square one.... 
Utterly fucking mind-bending....!!!!
comments.author: HeavensGremlin

comments.text: Ditch those glasses, you look like a porn producer from the eighties...
comments.author: Baj64

comments.text: A known BMW enthusiast calling an e28 M5 an e24? Sigh
comments.author: TheChocolateyGoodnes

comments.text: What makes you think he is smarter than the average American?
comments.author: Acct1941

comments.text: It says part 1.. Where is the rest??
comments.author: Ioannisthegreat7

comments.text: It was painful to watch this.
comments.author: GrotrianSeiler

comments.text:
No, please no. He is an embarrassment. I don't know why Chris gave him the 
time of day. He is the kind of American I run from.
comments.author: GrotrianSeiler

comments.text: where are parts 2-4?
comments.author: Jrome Miles

comments.text:
Vet nice show Alex watch my show supercharged gas guzzling low revving big 
torque tire smoking flame throwing with super models and energy drink 
sponsors
comments.author: Arthur Wall

comments.text: To myself yes ;) , not evo mag approved but I love it haha
comments.author: welshdude6669

comments.text:
Fat, unfunny, arrogant, geographically ignorant. Is alex roy the archetypal 
american?
comments.author: john marsh

comments.text: nice graduation present!
comments.author: Rachael Firth

comments.text:
It does indeed, one of my favourite roads in the world is that from 
Llangynog to Bala, having recently purchased an E46 clubsport upon 
finishing university, I enjoyed that very road far too much last weekend!
comments.author: welshdude6669

comments.text:
It would appear that Chris Harris embodies a kind of masculine style 
virtually unknown in the US. And now I discover that he is Welsh?? And that 
the roads of Wales border on the sublime! Who needs California?
comments.author: Adam Donovan

comments.text: The lambs on the brecon roads are cleverer than the older sheep.
comments.author: mutsnuts1989

comments.text:
Why, thank you. And like many parts of the British Isles, Wales has some 
seriously fun roads, perfect for something small and maneuverable like a 
Porsche, or a Caterham (in that latest CH vid with the Morgan 3-wheeler)
comments.author: Rachael Firth

comments.text:
I literally could not have put it better myself, that comment was quite the

comments.text:

to you welshdude6669 sir, that you and Chris Harris are one and the same!

knees, the dog's bollocks, the cat's pajamas, the hamster's 
Malteser-stuffed cheek pouches and the budgerigar's pocket-watch rolled 
into one animal-kingdom-esque collection of awesome and peerless skill. Mad 
props to Lord Harris of Hoon.

comments.text:
Alex started doing a segment on Fast Lane Daily a few years back. During 
sweeping changes to the show, the regular host Derick D lost most of his 
airtime hosting auto news in a comedic fashion to more high brow "new" 
content. Some of which involved Alex Roy. He immediately rubbed most 
viewers the wrong way with his smug know it all ego. I gave it a few months 
but it became unbearable. Many viewers unsubscribed. He's experienced 
though and could be ok if stopped being a wanker.
comments.author: David Hands

comments.text:
Oh cool! now that Alex Roy is here, I can resubscribe to Fast Lane daily! 
:D
